text: the film is called Jesus Henry Christ
and it's about a very precocious
actually genius child who goes in search
of his biological father and that pretty
much turns everybody's world upside down
I wrote the script as my last script in
film school and during the same time
that I wrote it I found love you know
too with the woman who eventually said
yes and became my wife you know and what
that basically did was it I don't know
it kind of just opened a new level of
emotion for me that was different than
everything that I had written before
everything that I wrote before and I
think this is part of like going to film
school is you write that angst film you
know or you write a series of those
films and I wanted this just to be
different and it was really liberating
writing Henry because it was one of
those scripts that I wrote in a couple
of weeks it just kind of poured out and
so I thank my wife for that he's Henry
Henry's the catalyst for growth and all
the other characters around him and in a
lot of ways he's not the traditional
protagonist that you find in a lot of
movies you know he acts but rather than
the supporting in most movies well I
think what you'll find is that the
supporting characters all reflect back
upon the protagonist you know in some
way or another Henry's actually the
mirror in this case and all the other
characters are reflected off of Henry
and through that reflection they see
parts of themselves that that maybe they
didn't want to see or or they just
turned away from but they're now forced
to see and that causes them to change
their behavior it causes them to change
who they are so in that sense Henry
becomes like you know whatever he
becomes the Sun and the water you know
that grows the plant that sort of thing
